/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefilesvijoseph edward shigley ( 1909–1994 ) undoubtedly one well-known respected contributors machine design education . authored coauthored eight books , including theory machines mechanisms ( john j. uicker , jr. ) , applied mechanics materials . coeditor-in-chief well-known standard handbook machine design . began machine design sole author 1956 , evolved mechanical engineering design , setting model textbooks . contributed first five editions text , along coauthors larry mitchell charles mischke . uncounted numbers students across world got first taste machine design shigley ’ textbook , literally become classic . nearly every mechanical engineer past half century referenced terminology , equations , procedures “ shigley. ” mcgraw-hill honored worked professor shigley 40 years , tribute lasting contribution textbook , title officially reflects many already come call it—shigley ’ mechanical engineering design . received bachelor ’ degree electrical mechanical engineering purdue university master science engineering mechanics university michigan , professor shigley pursued academic career clemson college 1936 1954. led position professor head mechanical design drawing clemson college . joined faculty department mechanical engineering university michigan 1956 , remained 22 years retirement 1978. professor shigley granted rank fellow american society mechanical engineers 1968. received asme mechanisms committee award 1974 , worcester reed warner medal outstanding contribution permanent literature engineering 1977 , asme machine design award 1985. joseph edward shigley indeed made difference . legacy shall continue.dedication joseph edward shigleybud98209_fm_i-xxii_1.indd page vi 12/9/13 4:52 pm f-494 bud98209_fm_i-xxii_1.indd page vi 12/9/13 4:52 pm f-494 rochester institute technology . 50 years experience teach-ing practicing mechanical engineering design . author mcgraw-hill textbook , advanced strength applied stress analysis , second edition ; coau- thor mcgraw-hill reference book , roark ’ formulas stress strain , eighth edition . awarded bme union college , msme university rochester , phd university massachusetts . licensed professional engineer state new york . j. keith nisbett associate professor associate chair mechanical engineering missouri university science technology . 30 years experience using teaching classic textbook . demon-strated steady stream teaching awards , including governor ’ award teaching excellence , devoted finding ways communicating concepts students . awarded bs , ms , phd university texas chapters reviewing material properties , stress analysis , stiffness deflection analysis , principles neces-sary remainder book . part 2 , failure prevention , consists two chapters prevention failure mechanical parts . machine parts fail designed prevent failure difficult questions , take two chapters answer , one preventing failure due static loads , preventing fatigue failure due time-varying , cyclic loads . part 3 , design mechanical elements , concepts parts 1 2 applied analysis , selection , design specific mechanical elements shafts , fasteners , weldments , springs , rolling contact bearings , film bearings , gears , belts , chains , wire ropes . part 4 , special topics , provides introductions two important methods used mechanical design , finite element analysis geometric mechanical engineering design 1–9 stress strength survival many products depends designer adjusts maximum stresses component less component ’ strength critical locations . designer must allow maximum stress less strength suffi-cient margin despite uncertainties , failure rare . focusing stress-strength comparison critical ( controlling ) location , often look “ strength geometry condition use. ” strengths magnitudes stresses something interest occurs , proportional limit , 0.2 percent-offset yielding , fracture ( see sec . 2–1 ) . many cases , events represent stress level loss function occurs . strength property material mechanical element . strength element depends choice , treatment , processing material . consider , example , shipment springs . associate strength specific spring . spring incorporated machine , external forces applied result load-induced stresses spring , magnitudes depend geometry independent material processing . spring removed machine undamaged , stress due external forces return zero . strength remains one properties spring . remember , , strength inherent property part , property built part use particular material process . various metalworking heat-treating processes , forging , rolling , cold forming , cause variations strength point point throughout part . spring cited quite likely strength outside coils different strength inside spring formed cold winding process , two sides may deformed amount . remember , , therefore , strength value given part may apply particular point set points part . book shall use capital letter denote strength , appropriate subscripts denote type strength . thus , yield strength , u ultimate strength , ssy shear yield strength , e endurance strength . accordance accepted engineering practice , shall employ greek letters ( sigma ) ( tau ) designate normal shear stresses , respectively . , various subscripts indicate special characteristic . example , 1 prin- cipal normal stress , normal stress component direction , r normal stress component radial direction . stress state property specific point within body , function load , geometry , temperature , manufacturing processing . sometimes neglected . review stress analysis basic load states geometry given chap . 3 . 1–10 uncertainty uncertainties machinery design abound . examples uncertainties concerning stress strength location , orientation , form features part . see chap . 20 overview gd & . choice tolerances choice tolerances designer ’ responsibility made arbitrarily . tolerances selected based combination assembly achieved reasonable balance considerations , entire design may need reconsidered . relationship tolerances functionality usually associated need assemble multiple parts . example , diameter expensive manufacturing methods . excessive precision part designer may seem like easy way achieve functionality , actually poor design choice limits manufacturing options drives cost . competitive costs , shown fig . 1–2 , designer generally thinking terms loosening tolerances much possible , still achieving desired functionality . choice dimensions dimensioning part designer ’ responsibility , ( 2–2 ) based net change length original length . plotting true stress-strain diagram , customary use term called true strain , sometimes , logarithmic strain . true strain sum incremental elongations divided current gauge length load p , e5 # l l0 dl l5ln l l0 ( 2–4 ) symbol e used represent true strain . important characteristic true stress-strain diagram ( fig . 2–4 ) true stress continually increases way fracture . thus , shown fig . 2–4 , true fracture stress f greater true ultimate stress u. contrast fig . 2–2a , engineering fracture strength f less engineering ultimate strength u. compression tests difficult conduct , geometry test specimens differs geometry used tension tests . reason specimen may buckle testing may difficult distribute stresses evenly . difficulties occur ductile materials bulge yielding . however , results plotted stress-strain diagram also , strength definitions applied used tensile testing . ductile materials compressive strengths tensile strengths . substantial differences occur tensile compressive strengths , however , figure 2–3 tension specimen necking.bud98209_ch02_041-084.indd page 44 9/23/13 4:24 pm f-496 bud98209_ch02_041-084.indd page 44 9/23/13 4:24 pm f-496 /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefilesmaterials 45 case cast irons , tensile compressive strengths stated separately , sut , suc , uc reported positive quantity . torsional strengths found twisting solid circular bars recording torque twist angle . results plotted torque-twist diagram . shear stresses specimen linear respect radial location , zero center specimen maximum outer radius r ( see chap . 3 ) . maximum shear stress max related angle twist u tmax5gr l0 u ( 2–5 ) u radians , r radius specimen , l 0 gauge length , g material stiffness property called shear modulus modulus rigidity . maximum shear stress also related applied torque tmax5tr j ( 2–6 ) j51 2pr4 polar second moment area cross section . torque-twist diagram similar fig . 2–2 , , using eqs . /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles56 mechanical engineering design 2–7 numbering systems society automotive engineers ( sae ) first recognize need , adopt system , numbering steels . later american iron steel institute ( aisi ) adopted similar system . 1975 sae published unified numbering system metals alloys ( uns ) ; system also contains cross-reference numbers material specifications . 7 uns uses letter prefix designate material , , example , g carbon alloy steels , aluminum alloys , c copper-base alloys , stainless corrosion-resistant steels . materials , enough agreement yet developed industry warrant establishment designation . steels , first two numbers following letter prefix indicate com-position , excluding carbon content . various compositions used follows : 7many materials discussed balance chapter listed appendix tables . sure review these.g10 plain carbon g11 free-cutting carbon steel sulfur phosphorus g13 manganeseg23 nickelg25 nickelg31 nickel-chromiumg33 nickel-chromiumg40 molybdenumg41 chromium-molybdenumg43 nickel-chromium-molybdenumg46 nickel-molybdenumg48 nickel-molybdenumg50 chromiumg51 chromiumg52 chromiumg61 chromium-vanadiumg86 chromium-nickel-molybdenumg87 chromium-nickel-molybdenumg92 manganese-silicong94 nickel-chromium-molybdenum second number pair refers approximate carbon content . thus , g10400 plain carbon steel nominal carbon content 0.40 percent ( 0.37 0.44 per-cent ) . fifth number following prefix used special situations . example , old designation aisi 52100 represents chromium alloy 100 points carbon . uns designation g52986 . uns designations stainless steels , prefix , utilize older aisi designations first three numbers following prefix . next two numbers reserved special purposes . first number group indicates approx-imate composition . thus 2 chromium-nickel-manganese steel , 3 chromium-nickel steel , 4 chromium alloy steel . sometimes stainless steels referred alloy content . thus s30200 often called 18-8 stainless steel , meaning 18 percent chromium 8 percent nickel . prefix aluminum group letter a. first number following prefix indicates processing . example , a9 wrought aluminum , a0 casting alloy . second number designates main alloy group shown table 2–1 . third number group used modify original alloy designate impurity limits . last two numbers refer alloys used basic group.bud98209_ch02_041-084.indd page 56 9/23/13 4:24 pm f-496 /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles58 mechanical engineering design sand , forms shell 5 10 mm thick around pattern . shell baked 400 700°f short time still pattern . stripped pattern placed storage use casting . next step shells assembled clamping , bolting , pasting ; placed backup material , steel shot ; molten metal poured cavity . thin shell permits heat conducted away solid-ification takes place rapidly . solidification takes place , plastic bond burned mold collapses . permeability backup material allows gases escape casting air-cool . aids obtaining fine-grain , stress-free casting . shell-mold castings feature smooth surface , draft quite small , close tolerances . general , rules governing sand casting also apply shell-mold casting . 2–10 investment casting investment casting uses pattern may made wax , plastic , mate-rial . mold made , pattern melted . thus mechanized method casting great many patterns necessary . mold material dependent upon melting point cast metal . thus plaster mold used materials others would require ceramic mold . pattern melted , mold baked fired ; firing completed , molten metal may poured hot mold allowed cool . number castings made , metal permanent molds may suitable . molds advantage surfaces smooth , bright , accurate , little , , machining required . metal-mold castings also known die castings centrifugal castings . 2–11 powder-metallurgy process powder-metallurgy process quantity-production process uses powders single metal , several metals , mixture metals nonmetals . consists essentially mechanically mixing powders , compacting dies high pressures , heating compacted part temperature less melting point major ingredient . particles united single strong part similar would obtained melting ingredients together . advantages ( 1 ) elimination scrap waste material , ( 2 ) elimination machining oper-ations , ( 3 ) low unit cost mass-produced , ( 4 ) exact control com-position . disadvantages ( 1 ) high cost dies , ( 2 ) lower physical properties , ( 3 ) higher cost materials , ( 4 ) limitations design , ( 5 ) limited range materials used . parts commonly made process oil-impregnated bearings , incandescent lamp filaments , cemented-carbide tips tools , permanent magnets . products made powder metallurgy : surgical implants , example . structure different obtained melting ingredients . 2–12 hot-working processes hot working meant processes rolling , forging , hot extrusion , hot pressing , metal heated recrystallization temperature.bud98209_ch02_041-084.indd page 58 9/23/13 4:24 pm f-496 bud98209_ch02_041-084.indd page 58 9/23/13 4:24 pm f-496 /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefilesmaterials 59 hot rolling usually used create bar material particular shape dimension . figure 2–11 shows various shapes commonly pro- duced hot-rolling process . available many different sizes well different materials . materials available hot-rolled bar sizes steel , aluminum , magnesium , copper alloys . tubing manufactured hot-rolling strip plate . edges strip rolled together , creating seams either butt-welded lap-welded . seamless tubing manufactured roll-piercing solid heated rod piercing mandrel . extrusion process great pressure applied heated metal billet blank , causing flow restricted orifice . process common materials low melting point , aluminum , copper , magnesium , lead , tin , zinc . stainless steel extrusions available limited basis . forging hot working metal hammers , presses , forging machines . common hot-working processes , forging produces refined grain struc-ture results increased strength ductility . compared castings , forgings greater strength weight . addition , drop forgings made smoother accurate sand castings , less machining necessary . however , initial cost forging dies usually greater cost patterns castings , although greater unit strength rather cost usually deciding factor two processes . 2–13 bud98209_ch02_041-084.indd page 71 9/23/13 4:24 pm f-496 /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles72 mechanical engineering design metals traditional engineering materials uniform , isotropic , nature . means material properties , strength , stiffness , thermal conductivity , independent position within material choice coordinate system . discontinuous nature composite reinforcements , though , means material properties vary position direction . example , epoxy resin reinforced continuous graphite fibers high strength stiffness direction fibers , low properties normal transverse fibers . reason , structures composite materials normally con-structed multiple plies ( laminates ) ply oriented achieve optimal structural stiffness strength performance . high strength-to-weight ratios , 5 times greater high-strength steels , achieved . high stiffness-to-weight ratios also obtained , much 8 times greater structural metals . reason , composite materials becoming popular automotive , marine , aircraft , spacecraft applications weight premium . directionality properties composite materials increases complexity structural analyses . isotropic materials fully defined two engineering con-stants : young ’ modulus e poisson ’ ratio n. single ply composite material , however , requires four constants , defined respect ply coordinate system . constants two young ’ moduli ( longitudinal modulus direction fibers , e 1 , transverse modulus normal fibers , e 2 ) , one poisson ’ ratio ( n12 , called major poisson ’ ratio ) , one shear modulus ( g 12 ) . fifth constant , minor poisson ’ ratio , n 21 , determined reciprocity relation , n 21ye2 5 n12ye1 . combining multiple plies oriented different angles makes struc- tural analysis complex structures unapproachable manual techniques . reason , computer software available calculate properties laminated com-posite construction . 15 2–21 /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefilesload stress analysis 87 free-body diagrams greatly simplify analysis complex structure machine suc- cessively isolating element studying analyzing use free-body diagrams . members treated manner , knowledge obtained assembled yield information concerning behavior total system . thus , free-body diagramming essentially means breaking complicated problem manageable segments , analyzing simple problems , , usually , putting information together . using free-body diagrams force analysis serves following important purposes : • diagram establishes directions reference axes , provides place record dimensions subsystem magnitudes directions known forces , helps assuming directions unknown forces . • diagram simplifies thinking provides place store one thought proceeding next . • diagram provides means communicating thoughts clearly unam-biguously people . • careful complete construction diagram clarifies fuzzy thinking bringing various points always apparent statement geometry total problem . thus , diagram aids understanding facets problem . • diagram helps planning logical attack problem setting mathematical relations . • diagram helps recording progress solution illustrating methods used . • diagram allows others follow reasoning , showing forces . loads present ( engineering applications assumed loads affect bending stresses minimally ) . • material isotropic homogeneous . • material obeys hooke ’ law . • beam initially straight cross section constant throughout beam length . • beam axis symmetry plane bending . • proportions beam would fail bending rather crushing , wrinkling , sidewise buckling . • plane cross sections beam remain plane bending . fig . 3–13 visualize portion straight beam acted upon positive bending moment shown curved arrow showing physical action moment together straight , double-headed , arrow indicating moment /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles162 mechanical engineering design real bodies deform load , either elastically plastically . body suf- ficiently insensitive deformation presumption rigidity affect analysis enough warrant nonrigid treatment . body deformation later proves negligible , declaring rigidity poor decision , poor assumption . wire rope flexible , tension robustly rigid distorts enormously attempts compressive loading . body rigid nonrigid . deflection analysis enters design situations many ways . snap ring , retain-ing ring , must flexible enough bent without permanent deformation assem-bled parts , must rigid enough hold assembled parts together . transmission , gears must supported rigid shaft . shaft bends much , , flexible , teeth mesh properly , result excessive impact , noise , wear , early failure . rolling sheet strip steel pre-scribed thicknesses , rolls must crowned , , curved , finished product uniform thickness . thus , design rolls necessary know exactly much bend sheet steel rolled . sometimes mechani-cal elements must designed particular force-deflection characteristic . suspension system automobile , example , must designed within narrow range achieve optimum vibration frequency conditions vehicle loading , human body comfortable within limited range frequencies . size load-bearing component often determined deflections , rather limits stress . chapter considers distortion single bodies due geometry ( shape ) loading , , briefly , behavior groups bodies . 4–1 given spring constant . 4–11 compression members—general analysis design compression members differ significantly members loaded tension torsion . take long rod pole , meterstick , apply gradually increasing compressive forces end , small axial deflections would happen first , stick would bend ( buckle ) , quickly bend much possibly fracture . try . extreme would occur saw , say , 5-mm length meterstick perform experiment short piece . would observe failure exhibits mashing specimen , , simple compressive failure . reasons convenient classify compression members according length according whether loading central eccentric . term column applied members except failure would simple pure com-pression . columns categorized : 1 long columns central loading 2 intermediate-length columns central loading 3 columns eccentric loading 4 struts short columns eccentric loading classifying columns makes possible develop methods analysis design specific category . furthermore , methods also reveal whether selected category appropriate particular problem . four sections follow correspond , respectively , four categories col-umns listed . 4–12 long columns central loading figure 4–18 shows long columns differing end ( boundary ) conditions . axial force p shown acts along centroidal axis column , simple compression member occurs low values force . however , certain conditions , p /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles204 mechanical engineering design 4–16 elastic stability section 4–12 presented conditions unstable behavior long , slender col- umns . elastic instability also occur structural members columns . compressive loads/stresses within long , thin structure cause structural insta-bilities ( buckling ) . compressive stress may elastic inelastic instabil-ity may global local . global instabilities cause catastrophic failure , whereas local instabilities may cause permanent deformation function failure catastrophic failure . buckling discussed sec . 4–12 global instability . however , consider wide flange beam bending . one flange compression , thin enough , develop localized buckling region bending moment maximum . localized buckling also occur web beam , transverse shear stresses present beam centroid . recall , case pure shear stress , stress transformation show 45° , compressive stress 5 2t exists . web sufficiently thin shear force v maximum , localized buckling web occur . reason , additional support form bracing typically applied locations high shear forces . 10 thin-walled beams bending buckle torsional mode illustrated fig . 4–24 . cantile ver beam loaded lateral force , f . f increases zero , end beam deflect negative direction normally accord- ing bending equation , 5 2fl 3y ( 3ei ) . however , beam long enough ratio b yh sufficiently small , critical value f beam collapse twisting mode shown . due compression bottom fibers beam cause fibers buckle sideways ( z direction ) . great many examples unstable structural behavior , thin-walled pressure vessels compression outer pressure inner vacuum , thin-walled open closed members torsion , thin arches compression , frames compression , shear panels . vast array applications complexity analyses , elaboration beyond scope book . intent section make reader aware possibilities potential safety issues . key issue designer aware unbraced part structural member thin , and/or long , compression ( directly indi-rectly ) , possibility buckling investigated . 11 unique applications , designer may need revert numerical solution using finite elements . depending application finite-element code available , analysis performed determine critical loading ( see fig . 4–25 composition . descriptors strength necessarily statistical nature , involving parameters mean , standard deviations , distributional identification . static load stationary force couple applied member . station- ary , force couple must unchanging magnitude , point points applica-tion , direction . static load produce axial tension compression , shear load , bending load , torsional load , combination . considered static , load change manner . chapter consider relations strength static loading order make decisions concerning material treatment , fabrication , geometry satisfying requirements functionality , safety , reliability , competi-tiveness , usability , manufacturability , marketability . far go list related scope examples . “ failure ” first word chapter title . pos-sibilities . chapter attention focused predictability permanent distortion separation . strength-sensitive situations designer must separate mean stress mean strength critical location bud98209_ch06_273-349.indd page 273 10/7/13 1:16 pm f-496 /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles274 mechanical engineering design chap . 5 considered analysis design parts subjected static loading . behavior machine parts entirely different subjected time-varying loading . chapter shall examine parts fail variable load-ing proportion successfully resist conditions . 6–1 introduction fatigue metals testing properties materials relate stress-strain diagram , load applied gradually , give sufficient time strain fully develop . furthermore , specimen tested destruction , stresses applied . testing kind applicable , known static conditions ; conditions closely approximate actual conditions many structural machine members subjected . condition frequently arises , however , stresses vary time fluctuate different levels . example , particular fiber surface rotating shaft subjected action bending loads undergoes tension compression revolution shaft . shaft part electric motor rotating 1725 rev/min , fiber stressed tension compression 1725 times minute . , addition , shaft also axially loaded ( would , example , helical worm gear ) , axial component stress superposed upon bending component . case , stress always present one fiber , level stress fluctuating . kinds loading occurring machine members produce stresses called variable , repeated , alternating , fluctuating stresses . often , machine members found failed action repeated fluctuating stresses ; yet careful analysis reveals actual maximum stresses well ultimate strength material , quite frequently even yield strength . distinguishing characteristic failures stresses repeated large number times . hence failure called fatigue failure . machine parts fail statically , usually develop large deflection , stress exceeded yield strength , part replaced fracture actually occurs . thus many static failures give visible warning advance . fatigue failure gives warning ! sudden total , hence dangerous . relatively simple design static failure , knowledge comprehensive . fatigue much complicated phenomenon , partially understood , engineer seeking competence must acquire much knowledge subject possible . fatigue failure appearance similar brittle fracture , fracture surfaces flat perpendicular stress axis absence necking . fracture features fatigue failure , however , quite different static brittle fracture arising three stages development . stage initiation one microcracks due cyclic plastic deformation followed crystallographic propagation extending two five grains origin . stage cracks normally discernible naked eye . stage ii progresses microcracks mac-rocracks forming parallel plateau-like fracture surfaces separated longitudinal ridges . plateaus generally smooth normal direction maximum tensile stress . surfaces wavy dark light bands referred beach marks clamshell marks , seen fig . 6–1 . cyclic loading , cracked surfaces open close , rubbing together , beach mark appearance depends bud98209_ch06_273-349.indd page 274 10/7/13 1:16 pm f-496 bud98209_ch06_273-349.indd influences failure pattern . fatigue failure due crack formation propagation . fatigue crack typically initiate discontinuity material cyclic stress maxi-mum . discontinuities arise : • design rapid changes cross section , keyways , holes , etc . stress concen- trations occur discussed secs . 3–13 5–2 . • elements roll and/or slide ( bearings , gears , cams , etc . ) high contact pressure , developing concentrated subsurface contact stresses ( sec . 3–19 ) cause surface pitting spalling many cycles load . • carelessness locations stamp marks , tool marks , scratches , burrs ; poor joint design ; improper assembly ; fabrication faults . • composition material processed rolling , forging , casting , extru-sion , drawing , heat treatment , etc . microscopic submicroscopic surface subsurface discontinuities arise , inclusions foreign material , alloy segre-gation , voids , hard precipitated particles , crystal discontinuities . various conditions accelerate crack initiation /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles352 mechanical engineering design 7–1 introduction shaft rotating member , usually circular cross section , used transmit power motion . provides axis rotation , oscillation , elements gears , pulleys , flywheels , cranks , sprockets , like controls geometry motion . axle nonrotating member carries torque used support rotating wheels , pulleys , like . automotive axle true axle ; term carryover horse-and-buggy era , wheels rotated nonrotating members . nonrotating axle readily designed analyzed static beam , warrant special attention given chapter rotating shafts subject fatigue loading . really nothing unique shaft requires special treatment beyond basic methods already developed previous chapters . however , ubiquity shaft many machine design applications , advantage giving shaft design closer inspection . complete shaft design much interdependence design components . design machine dictate certain gears , pulleys , bearings , elements least partially analyzed size spacing tentatively determined . chapter 18 provides complete case study power transmission , focusing overall design process . chapter , details shaft examined , including following : • material selection • geometric layout • stress strength static strength fatigue strength • deflection rigidity bending deflection torsional deflection slope bearings shaft-supported elements shear deflection due transverse loading short shafts • vibration due natural frequency deciding approach shaft sizing , necessary realize stress analysis specific point shaft made using shaft geometry vicinity point . thus geometry entire shaft needed . design usually possible locate critical areas , size meet strength requirements , size rest shaft meet requirements shaft-supported elements . deflection slope analyses made geometry entire shaft defined . thus deflection function geometry everywhere , whereas stress section interest function local geometry . reason , shaft design allows consideration stress first . , tentative values shaft dimensions established , determination deflections slopes made . 7–2 shaft materials deflection affected strength , rather stiffness represented modulus elasticity , essentially constant steels . reason , rigidity controlled material decisions , geometric decisions.bud98209_ch07_350-400.indd page 352 10/16/13 7:52 f-496 bud98209_ch07_350-400.indd page 352 10/16/13 7:52 f-496 /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefilesshafts shaft components 353 necessary strength resist loading stresses affects choice materials treatments . many shafts made low carbon , cold-drawn hot-rolled steel , aisi 1020-1050 steels . significant strengthening heat treatment high alloy content often warranted . fatigue failure reduced moderately increase strength , certain level adverse effects endurance limit notch sensitivity begin counteract benefits higher strength . good practice start inexpensive , low medium carbon steel first time design calculations . strength considerations turn dominate deflection , higher strength material tried , allowing shaft sizes reduced excess deflection becomes issue . cost material processing must weighed need smaller shaft diameters . warranted , typical alloy steels heat treatment include aisi 1340-50 , 3140-50 , 4140 , 4340 , 5140 , 8650. shafts usually ’ need surface hardened unless serve actual journal bearing surface . typical material choices surface hardening include carburizing grades aisi 1020 , 4320 , 4820 , 8620. cold drawn steel usually used diameters 3 inches . nom-inal diameter bar left unmachined areas require fitting components . hot rolled steel machined . large shafts requir-ing much material removal , residual stresses may tend cause warping . concentricity important , may necessary rough machine , heat treat remove residual stresses increase strength , finish machine final dimensions . approaching material selection , amount produced salient factor . low production , turning usual primary shaping process . economic view-point may require removing least material . high production may permit volume-conservative shaping method ( hot cold forming , casting ) , minimum material shaft become design goal . cast iron may specified production quantity high , gears integrally cast shaft . properties shaft locally depend history—cold work , cold forming , rolling fillet features , heat treatment , including quenching medium , agitation , tempering regimen . 1 stainless steel may appropriate environments . 7–3 shaft layout general layout shaft accommodate shaft elements , e.g. , gears , bearings , pulleys , must specified early design process order perform free body force analysis obtain shear-moment diagrams . geometry shaft generally stepped cylinder . use shaft shoulders excellent means axially locating shaft elements carry thrust loads . figure 7–1 shows example stepped shaft supporting gear 359 shafts transmit torque portion shaft . typically torque comes shaft one gear leaves shaft another gear . free body diagram shaft allow torque section determined . torque often relatively constant steady state operation . shear stress due torsion greatest outer surfaces . bending moments shaft determined shear bending moment diagrams . since shaft problems incorporate gears pulleys introduce forces two planes , shear bending moment diagrams generally needed two planes . resultant moments obtained summing moments vectors points interest along shaft . phase angle moments important since shaft rotates . steady bending moment produce completely reversed moment rotating shaft , specific stress element alternate compression tension every revolution shaft . normal stress due bending moments greatest outer surfaces . situations bearing located end shaft , stresses near bearing often critical since bending moment small . axial stresses shafts due axial components transmitted helical gears tapered roller bearings almost always negligibly small compared bending moment stress . often also constant , contribute little fatigue . consequently , usually acceptable neglect axial important mechanical inven- tion . basis power screws , change angular motion linear motion transmit power develop large forces ( presses , jacks , etc . ) , threaded fasten-ers , important element nonpermanent joints . book presupposes knowledge elementary methods fastening . typical methods fastening joining parts use devices bolts , nuts , cap screws , setscrews , rivets , spring retainers , locking devices , pins , keys , welds , adhesives . studies engineering graphics metal processes often include instruction various joining methods , curiosity person interested mechanical engineering naturally results acquisition good background knowledge fastening methods . contrary first impressions , subject one inter-esting entire field mechanical design . one key targets current design manufacture reduce number fasteners . however , always need fasteners facilitate disas-sembly whatever purposes . example , jumbo jets boeing ’ 747 require many 2.5 million fasteners , cost several dollars apiece . keep costs , aircraft manufacturers , subcontractors , constantly review new fastener designs , installation techniques , tooling . number innovations fastener field period might care mention tremendous . overwhelming variety fasteners available designer ’ selection . serious designers generally keep specific notebooks fasteners alone . methods joining parts extremely important engineering quality design , necessary thorough understanding per-formance fasteners joints conditions use design . 8–1 thread standards definitions terminology screw threads , illustrated fig . 8–1 , explained follows : pitch distance adjacent thread forms measured parallel thread axis . pitch u.s. units reciprocal number thread forms per inch n. major diameter largest diameter screw thread . minor ( root ) diameter r smallest diameter screw thread . pitch diameter dp theoretical diameter major minor diameters . lead l , shown , distance nut moves parallel screw axis nut given one turn . single thread , fig . 8–1 , lead pitch . multiple-threaded product one two threads cut beside ( imagine two strings wound side side around pencil ) . standardized products screws , bolts , nuts single threads ; double-threaded screw lead equal twice pitch , triple-threaded screw lead equal 3 times pitch , . threads made according right-hand rule unless otherwise noted . , bolt turned clockwise , bolt advances toward nut . american national ( unified ) thread standard approved coun- try great britain use standard threaded products . thread angle 60° crests thread may either flat rounded . processes welding , brazing , soldering , cementing , gluing—processes used exten-sively manufacturing today . whenever parts assembled fabricated , usually good cause considering one processes preliminary design work . particularly sections joined thin , one methods may lead significant savings . elimination individual fasteners , holes assembly costs , important factor . also , methods allow rapid machine assembly , furthering attractiveness . riveted permanent joints common means fastening rolled steel shapes one another form permanent joint . childhood fascination seeing cherry-red hot rivet thrown tongs across building skeleton unerringly caught person conical bucket , hammered pneumatically final shape , gone . two developments relegated riveting lesser prominence . /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles490 mechanical engineering design 9–8 resistance welding heating consequent welding occur electric current passed several parts pressed together called resistance welding . spot weld- ing seam welding forms resistance welding often used . advantages resistance welding forms speed , accurate regulation time heat , uniformity weld , mechanical properties result . addition process easy automate , filler metal fluxes needed . spot- seam-welding processes illustrated schematically fig . 9–23 . seam welding actually series overlapping spot welds , since current applied pulses work moves rotating electrodes . failure resistance weld occurs either shearing weld tearing metal around weld . possibility tearing , good practice avoid loading resistance-welded joint tension . thus , part , design spot seam loaded pure shear . shear stress simply load divided area spot . thinner sheet pair welded may tear , strength spot welds often specified stating load per spot based thickness thinnest sheet . strengths best obtained experiment . somewhat larger factors safety used parts fastened spot welding rather bolts rivets , account metallurgical changes materials due welding . 9–9 adhesive bonding5 use polymeric adhesives join components structural , semistructural , nonstructural applications expanded greatly recent years result unique advantages adhesives may offer certain assembly processes devel-opment new adhesives improved robustness environmental acceptability . increasing complexity modern assembled structures diverse types materials used led many joining applications would possible conventional joining techniques . adhesives also used either conjunction ( ) ( b ) figure 9–23 ( ) spot welding ; ( b ) seam welding . 5for extensive discussion topic , see j. e. shigley c. r. mischke , mechanical engineering design , 6th ed. , mcgraw-hill , new york , 2001 , sec . 9–11 . section prepared assistance professor david a. dillard , professor engineering science mechanics director center adhesive sealant science , virginia polytechnic institute state university , blacksburg , virginia , encouragement technical support bonding systems division 3m , saint paul , minnesota.bud98209_ch09_467-508.indd page 490 10/20/13 9:18 f-496 bud98209_ch09_467-508.indd page 490 10/20/13 9:18 f-496 /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefileswelding , bonding , design permanent joints 491 replace mechanical fasteners welds . reduced weight , sealing capabilities , reduced part count assembly time , well improved fatigue corrosion resistance , combine provide designer opportunities customized assembly . worldwide size adhesive sealant industry approximately 40 billion euro dollars , united states market 12 billion us dollars . 6 figure 9–24 illus- trates numerous places adhesives used modern automobile . indeed , fabrication many modern vehicles , devices , structures dependent adhesives . well-designed joints proper processing procedures , use adhesives result significant reductions weight . eliminating mechanical fasteners elim-inates weight fasteners , also may permit use thinner-gauge materials stress concentrations associated holes eliminated . capability polymeric adhesives dissipate energy significantly reduce noise , vibration , harshness ( nvh ) , crucial modern automobile performance . adhesives used assemble heat-sensitive materials components might damaged drilling holes mechanical fasteners . used join dissimilar mate-rials thin-gauge stock joined means . types adhesive numerous adhesive types various applications . may classified variety ways depending chemistry ( e.g. , epoxies , polyurethanes , poly-imides ) , form ( e.g. , paste , liquid , film , pellets , tape ) , type ( e.g. , hot melt , reactive hot melt , thermosetting , pressure sensitive , contact ) , load-carrying capability ( structural , semistructural , nonstructural ) . structural adhesives relatively strong adhesives normally used well glass transition temperature ; common examples include epoxies certain acrylics . adhesives carry significant stresses , lend structural 104 1391221 815 8 21 9 36 13 1 1511 147exterior trim sound insulationbrake/ transmissionwheel housingbody-in-whiteinterior trim bumper assemblyenginecompartmenthem flangewindshield/ windows exterior body panels light assembliesantiflutter panelreinforcementspaint shop 4 10 10 figure 9–24 diagram automobile body showing least 15 locations adhesives sealants could used used . particular note made windshield ( 8 ) , considered load-bearing structure modern automobiles adhesively bonded . also attention paid hem flange bonding ( 1 ) , adhesives used bond seal . adhesives used bond friction surfaces brakes clutches ( 10 ) . antiflutter adhesive bonding ( 2 ) helps control deformation hood trunk lids wind shear . thread-sealing adhesives used engine applications ( 12 ) . /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles492 mechanical engineering design applications . many engineering applications , semistructural applications ( fail- ure would less critical ) nonstructural applications ( headliners , etc. , aesthetic purposes ) also significant interest design engineer , providing cost-effective means required assembly finished products . include contact adhesives , solution emulsion containing elastomeric adhesive coated onto adherends , solvent allowed evaporate , two adherends brought contact . examples include rubber cement adhesives used bond laminates countertops . pressure-sensitive adhesives low modulus elastomers deform easily small pressures , permitting wet surfaces . substrate adhesive brought intimate contact , van der waals forces sufficient maintain contact provide relatively durable bonds . pressure-sensitive adhesives normally purchased tapes labels nonstructural applications , although also double-sided foam tapes used semistructural applications . name implies , hot melts become liquid heated , wetting surfaces cooling solid polymer . materials increasingly applied wide array engineering applications sophisticated versions glue guns popular use . anaerobic adhesives cure within narrow spaces deprived oxygen ; materials widely used mechanical engineering applications lock bolts bearings place . cure adhesives may induced exposure ultraviolet light electron beams , may catalyzed certain materials ubiquitous many surfaces , water . table 9–7 practice normally requires adhesive joints constructed manner adhesive carries load shear rather tension . bonds typically much stronger loaded shear rather tension across bond plate . lap-shear joints represent important family joints , test specimens evaluate adhesive properties actual incorporation practi-cal designs . generic types lap joints commonly arise illustrated fig. 9–25 . . effort point problems associated practice , astm d4896 outlines concerns associated taking simplistic view stresses within lap joints . 1938 , o. v olkersen presented analysis lap joint , known design considerations single-lap joints beyond scope chapter , one note load eccentricity important aspect stress state single-lap joints . adherend bending result shear stresses may much double given double-lap configuration ( given total bond area ) . addition , peel stresses quite large often account joint failure . finally , plastic bending adherends lead high strains , less ductile adhesives withstand , leading bond failure well . bending stresses adherends end overlap four times greater average stress within adherend ; thus , must considered design . figure 9–28 shows shear peel stresses present typical single-lap joint corresponds astm d1002 test specimen . note shear stresses significantly larger predicted v olkersen analysis , result increased adhesive strains associ-ated adherend bending . joint design basic guidelines used adhesive joint design include : • design place bondline shear , peel . beware peel stresses focused bond terminations . necessary , reduce peel stresses tapering adherend ends , increasing bond area peel stresses occur , utilizing rivets bond termina-tions peel stresses initiate failures . • possible , use adhesives adequate ductility . ability adhesive yield reduces stress concentrations associated ends joints increases toughness resist debond propagation . • recognize environmental limitations adhesives surface preparation methods . exposure water , solvents , diluents significantly degrade adhesive performance situations , displacing adhesive surface degrading polymer . certain adhesives may susceptible environmental stress cracking presence certain solvents . exposure ultraviolet light also degrade adhesives.bud98209_ch09_467-508.indd page 496 10/20/13 9:18 f-496 bud98209_ch09_467-508.indd page 496 10/20/13 9:18 f-496 inspections bonds possible . missing rivet bolt often easy detect , debonds unsatisfactory adhesive bonds readily apparent . • allow sufficient bond area joint tolerate debonding going critical . increases likelihood debonds detected . regions overall bond relatively low stress levels significantly improve durability reliability . • possible , bond multiple surfaces offer support loads direction . bonding attachment single surface place peel stresses bond , whereas bonding several adjacent planes tends permit arbitrary loads carried predominantly shear . • adhesives used conjunction 1018 steel , welded e6010 electrode . assume wave action boat create force f greater 1200 lbf . ( ) determine moment force f centroid weld g. moment produces shear stress throat resisting bending action “ tension ” “ compression ” c. ( b ) find force component f produces shear stress throat resisting “ tension ” throughout weld . ( c ) find force component f x produces in-line shear throughout weld . ( ) using table 9–2 , determine , iu , bracket . ( e ) find shear stress 1 due f , shear stress 2 due f x , combine find t. ( f ) find factor safety guarding shear yielding weldment . since weld material comprised mix electrode material base material , take conservative approach utilizing strength weaker material . ( g ) find factor safety guarding static failure parent metal weld . distance coil axis apply torque . frequently encountered ( least expensive ) end straight torsion end . intercoil friction avoided com-pletely , spring wound pitch separates body coils . helical coil torsion springs usually used rod arbor reactive support ends built , maintain alignment , provide buckling resis-tance necessary . wire torsion spring bending , contrast torsion encountered helical coil compression extension springs . springs designed wind tighter service . applied torque increases , inside diameter coil decreases . care must taken coils interfere pin , rod , arbor . bending thus called constant- force spring . equivalent zero spring rate . springs also manu-factured either positive negative spring rate . volute spring , shown fig . 10–13a , wide , thin strip , “ flat , ” material wound flat coils fit inside one another . since coils stack , solid height spring width strip . variable-spring scale , compression volute spring , obtained permitting coils contact support . thus , deflection increases , number active coils decreases . volute spring another important advantage obtained round-wire springs : coils wound contact slide one another action , sliding friction serve damp vibrations unwanted transient disturbances.figure 10–11 load-deflection curves belleville springs . problems rein-force learning experience . four components tapered roller bearing assembly • cone ( inner ring ) • cup ( outer ring ) • tapered rollers • cage ( spacer-retainer ) assembled bearing consists two separable parts : ( 1 ) cone assembly : cone , rollers , cage ; ( 2 ) cup . bearings made single-row , two-row , four-row , thrust-bearing assemblies . additionally , auxiliary components . however , even external thrust load present , radial load induce thrust reaction within bearing taper . avoid separation races rollers , thrust must resisted equal opposite force . one way generating force always use least two tapered roller bearings shaft . two bearings mounted cone backs facing , configuration called direct mounting , cone fronts fac-ing , called indirect mounting . note use washers cone backs . maximum stiffness resistance shaft misalignment desired , pairs angular-contact ball bearings ( fig . 11–2 ) often used arrangement called duplexing . bearings manufactured duplex mounting rings ground offset , pair bearings tightly clamped together , preload automatically established . shown fig . 11–24 , three mounting arrangements used . face-to-face mounting , called df , take heavy radial loads thrust loads either direction . db mounting ( back back ) greatest aligning stiffness also good heavy radial loads thrust loads either direction . tandem arrangement , called dt mounting , used thrust always direction ; since two bearings thrust functions direction , preload , required , must obtained manner . bearings usually mounted rotating ring press fit , whether inner outer ring . stationary ring mounted push fit . permits stationary ring creep mounting slightly , bringing new portions ring load-bearing zone equalize wear . wear , heating machine parts move relative . lubricant substance , inserted moving surfaces , accomplishes purposes . sleeve bearing , shaft , journal , rotates oscillates within sleeve , bushing , relative motion sliding . antifriction bearing , main relative motion rolling . follower may either roll slide cam . gear teeth mate combination rolling sliding . pistons slide within cylinders . applications require lubrication reduce friction , wear , heating . field application journal bearings immense . crankshaft connecting-rod bearings automotive engine must operate thousands miles high temperatures varying load conditions . journal bearings used steam turbines power-generating stations said reliabilities approaching 100 per-cent . extreme thousands applications loads light service relatively unimportant ; simple , easily installed bearing required , using little lubrication . cases antifriction bearing might poor answer cost , elaborate enclosures , close tolerances , radial space required , high speeds , increased inertial effects . instead , nylon bearing requir-ing lubrication , powder-metallurgy bearing lubrication “ built , ” bronze bearing ring oiling , wick feeding types lubrication five distinct forms lubrication may identified : 1 hydrodynamic 2 hydrostatic 3 elastohydrodynamic 4 boundary 5 solid film hydrodynamic lubrication means load-carrying surfaces bearing separated relatively thick film lubricant , prevent metal-to-metal contact , stability thus obtained explained laws fluid mechanics . hydrodynamic lubrication depend upon introduction lubricant pressure , though may occur ; require existence adequate supply times . film pressure created moving surface pulling lubricant wedge-shaped zone velocity sufficiently high create pressure necessary separate surfaces load bearing . hydrodynamic lubrication also called full-film , fluid , lubrication.bud98209_ch12_609-664.indd page 610 10/30/13 9:29 pm f-494 bud98209_ch12_609-664.indd pressure-fed bearings load-carrying capacity self-contained natural-circulating journal bearings quite restricted . factor limiting better performance heat-dissipation capabil-ity bearing . first thought way increase heat dissipation cool sump external fluid water . high-temperature problem film heat generated cooling possible film later . protect exceeding maximum allowable temperature lubri-cant . second alternative reduce temperature rise film dramatically increasing rate lubricant flow . lubricant reducing temperature rise . water-cooled sump may still picture . increase lubricant flow , external pump must used lubricant supplied pressures tens pounds per square inch gage . lubricant supplied bearing pressure , bearings called pressure-fed bearings . force greater flow bearing thus obtain increased cooling effect , common practice use circumferential groove center bearing , oil-supply hole located opposite load-bearing zone . bearing shown fig . 12–27 . effect groove create two half-bearings , smaller lyd ratio original . groove divides pressure-distribution curve two lobes reduces minimum film thickness , wide acceptance among lubrication engineers bearings carry load without overheating . set method solution oil flow , shall assume groove ample enough pressure drop groove small . initially neglect eccentricity apply correction factor condition /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefileslubrication journal bearings 649 length-diameter ratio l yd bearing depends upon whether expected run thin-film-lubrication conditions . long bearing ( large lyd ratio ) reduces coefficient friction side flow oil therefore desirable thin-film boundary-value lubrication present . hand , forced-feed positive lubrication present , l yd ratio relatively small . short bear- ing length results greater flow oil ends , thus keeping bearing cooler . current practice use l yd ratio unity , general , increase ratio thin-film lubrication likely occur decrease thick-film lubrication high temperatures . shaft deflection likely severe , short bearing used prevent metal-to-metal contact ends bearings . always consider use partial bearing high temperatures problem , relieving non-load-bearing area bearing substan-tially reduce heat generated . two conflicting requirements good bearing material must satisfactory compressive fatigue strength resist externally applied loads must soft low melting point low modulus elasticity . second set requirements necessary permit material wear break , since material conform slight irregularities absorb release foreign particles . resistance wear coefficient friction also impor-tant bearings must operate , least part time , thin-film boundary lubrication . additional considerations selection good bearing material abil-ity resist corrosion , course , cost producing bearing . commonly used materials listed table 12–6 , together composition characteristics . bearing life increased substantially depositing layer babbitt , white metal , thicknesses 0.001 0.014 steel backup material . fact , copper-lead layer steel provide strength , combined babbitt overlay enhance surface conformability corrosion resistance , makes excellent bearing . small bushings thrust collars often expected run thin-film bound-ary lubrication . case , improvements solid bearing material table 12–6 characteristics bearing alloys thickness , sae clearance load corrosion alloy name number ratio r/c capacity resistance tin-base babbitt 0.022 12 bushing made casting , drawing machining , using powder-metallurgy process . lined bush-ing usually split type . one method manufacture molten lining material cast continuously thin strip steel . babbitted strip processed presses , shavers , broaches , resulting lined bushing . type grooving may cut bushings . bushings assembled press fit finished boring , reaming , burnishing . flanged nomenclature 667 13–3 conjugate action 669 13–4 involute properties 670 13–5 fundamentals 670 13–6 contact ratio 676 13–7 interference 677 13–8 forming gear teeth 679 13–9 straight bevel gears 682 13–10 parallel helical gears 683 13–11 worm gears 687 13–12 tooth systems 688 13–13 gear trains 690 13–14 force analysis—spur gearing 697 13–15 force analysis—bevel gearing 701 13–16 force analysis—helical gearing 704 13–17 force analysis—worm gearing 706gears—general13 665bud98209_ch13_665-724.indd page 665 10/30/13 9:32 pm f-494 bud98209_ch13_665-724.indd page 665 10/30/13 9:32 pm f-494 /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles666 mechanical engineering design chapter addresses gear geometry , kinematic relations , forces transmit- ted four principal types gears : spur , helical , bevel , worm gears . forces transmitted meshing gears supply torsional moments shafts motion power transmission create forces moments affect shaft bearings . next two chapters address stress , strength , safety , reli-ability four types gears . 13–1 types gears spur gears , illustrated fig . 13–1 , teeth parallel axis rotation used transmit motion one shaft another , parallel , shaft . types , spur gear simplest , reason , used develop primary kinematic relationships tooth form . helical gears , shown fig . 13–2 , teeth inclined axis rotation . helical gears used applications spur gears , used , noisy , gradual engagement teeth meshing . inclined tooth also develops thrust loads bending couples , present spur gearing . sometimes helical gears used transmit motion nonparallel shafts . bevel gears , shown fig . 13–3 , teeth formed conical surfaces used mostly transmitting motion intersecting shafts . figure actually illustrates straight-tooth bevel gears . spiral bevel gears cut tooth longer straight , forms circular arc . hypoid gears quite similar spiral bevel gears except shafts offset nonintersecting . figure 13–1 spur gears used transmit rotary motion parallel shafts . figure 13–2 helical gears used transmit motion parallel nonparallel shafts.bud98209_ch13_665-724.indd page 666 area , proportional face width gear , becomes significant . helical gears subject shaft bearings radial thrust loads . thrust loads become high objectionable reasons , may desirable use double helical gears . double helical gear ( herringbone ) equivalent two helical gears opposite hand , mounted side side shaft . develop opposite thrust reactions thus cancel thrust load . two single helical gears ( ) pinion bending fatigue imposes power limitation ? use gerber criteria compen- sate one-way bending . ( b ) pinion surface fatigue imposes power limitation ? gear identical strengths pinion regard material properties . ( c ) determine power limitations due gear bending wear . /204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles/204/mh01996/bud98209_disk1of1/0073398209/bud98209_pagefiles778 mechanical engineering design american gear manufacturers association ( agma ) established standards analysis design various kinds bevel worm gears . chapter 14 introduction agma methods spur helical gears contains many definitions terms used chapter . agma established similar methods types gearing , follow general approach . 15–1 bevel gearing—general bevel gears may classified follows : • straight bevel gears • spiral bevel gears • zerol bevel gears • hypoid gears • spiroid gears straight bevel gear illustrated fig . 13–35 , p. 701. gears usu- ally used pitch-line velocities 1000 ft/min ( 5 m/s ) noise level important consideration . available many stock sizes less expensive produce bevel gears , especially small quantities . spiral bevel gear shown fig . 15–1 ; definition spiral angle illustrated fig . 15–2 . gears recommended higher speeds noise level important consideration . spiral bevel gears bevel coun-terpart helical gear ; seen fig . 15–1 pitch surfaces nature contact straight bevel gears except differences brought spiral-shaped teeth . zerol bevel gear patented gear curved teeth zero spiral angle . axial thrust loads permissible zerol bevel gears large spiral bevel gear , often used instead straight bevel gears . zerol bevel gear generated tool used regular spiral bevel gears . design purposes , use procedure straight bevel gears simply substitute zerol bevel gear . figure 15–1 spiral bevel gears . transmit high torque , even low speeds ; require positive engagement ample release force . centrifugal clutch used mostly automatic operation . spring used , torque transmitted proportional square speed . particularly useful electric-motor drives , starting , driven machine comes speed without shock . springs also used prevent engagement cer-tain motor speed reached , shock may occur . magnetic clutches particularly useful automatic remote-control systems . clutches also useful drives subject complex load cycles ( see sec . 11–7 ) . hydraulic pneumatic clutches also useful drives complex load-ing cycles automatic machinery , robots . fluid flow con-trolled remotely using solenoid valves . clutches also available disk , cone , multiple-plate clutches . braking systems , internal-shoe drum brake used mostly automotive applications . analyze internal-shoe device , refer fig . 16–4 , shows shoe pivoted point , actuating force acting end shoe . since shoe long , make assumption distribution normal forces uni-form . mechanical arrangement permits pressure applied heel , therefore assume pressure point zero . usual practice omit friction material short distance away heel ( point ) . eliminates interference , material would contribute little performance anyway , shown . designs hinge pin made movable provide additional heel pressure . gives effect floating figure 16–3 internal expanding centrifugal-acting rim clutch . along cotton lining , asbestos lining widely used brake material heavy machinery . molded-asbestos linings contain asbestos fiber friction modifiers ; thermoset polymer used , heat , form rigid flexible machine elements used conveying systems transmission power comparatively long dis-tances . often happens elements used replacement gears , shafts , bearings , relatively rigid power-transmission devices . many cases use simplif ies design machine substantially reduces cost . addition , since elements elastic usually quite long , play important part absorbing shock loads damping isolating effects vibration . important advantage far machine life concerned . flexible elements infinite life . used , important establish inspection schedule guard wear , aging , loss elasticity . elements replaced first sign deterioration . 17–1 belts four principal types belts shown , characteristics , table 17–1 . crowned pulleys used flat belts , grooved pulleys , sheaves , accepted standard , wire twisted one direction form strands , strands twisted opposite direction form rope . completed rope visible wires approximately parallel axis rope . regular-lay ropes kink untwist easy handle . lang-lay ropes wires strand strands rope twisted direction , hence outer wires run diagonally across axis rope . lang-lay ropes resistant abrasive wear failure due fatigue regular-lay ropes , likely kink untwist . standard ropes made hemp core , supports lubricates strands . rope subjected heat , either steel center wire-strand center must used . wire rope designated , precise sequence steps design process . nature , design iterative process necessary make tentative choices , build skeleton design , determine parts design critical . however , much time saved understanding dependencies parts problem , allowing designer know parts affected given change . section , outline presented , short explanation step . details discussed following sections . • power torque requirements . power considerations addressed first , determine overall sizing needs entire system . necessary speed torque ratio input output must determined addressing gear/pulley sizing . • gear specification . necessary gear ratios torque transmission issues addressed selection appropriate gears . note full force analysis shafts yet needed , transmitted loads required specify gears . • shaft layout . general layout shaft , including axial location gears bearings must specified . decisions transmit torque gears shaft need made ( keys , splines , etc . ) , well hold gears bearings place ( retaining rings , press fits , nuts , etc. ) . however , necessary point size elements , since standard sizes allow esti-mation stress-concentration factors . • force analysis . gear/pulley diameters known , axial locations gears bearings known , free-body , shear force , bending moment diagrams shafts produced . forces bearings determined . • shaft material selection . since fatigue design depends heavily material choice , usually easier make reasonable material selection first , check satisfactory results . • shaft design stress ( fatigue static ) . point , stress design shaft adjusted neces-sary specific part task , complete analysis start finish provide final check specific safety factors actual system . 18–2 power torque requirements power transmission systems typically specified power capacity , example , 40-horsepower gearbox . rating specifies combination torque speed unit endure . remember , ideal case , power equals power , refer power throughout system . reality , small losses due factors like friction bearings gears . many transmission systems , losses rolling bearings negligible . gears reasonably high efficiency , 1 2 percent power loss pair meshed gears . thus , double-reduction gearbox fig . 18–1 , two pairs meshed gears output power likely 2 4 percent less input power . since small loss , common speak simply power system , rather input power output power . flat belts timing belts efficiencies typically mid upper 90 percent range . v belts worm gears efficiencies may dip much lower , requiring distinction necessary input power obtain desired output power . torque , hand , typically constant throughout transmission system . remember power equals product torque speed . since power 5 power , know gear train h 5t ivi5tovo ( 18–1 ) constant power , gear ratio decrease angular velocity simulta-neously increase torque . gear ratio , train value , gear train e 5v oyvi5tiyto ( 18–2 ) typical power transmission design problem specify desired power capacity , along either input output angular velocities , input output torques . usually tolerance specified output values . specific gears specified , actual output values determined . , etc. , analyzed quite easily basic methods mechanics provide closed-form solutions . actual com- ponents , however , rarely simple , designer forced less effective approximations closed-form solutions , experimentation , numerical methods . great many numerical techniques used engineering applications digital computer useful . mechanical design , computer- aided design ( cad ) software heavily employed , analysis method integrates well cad finite-element analysis ( fea ) . mathematical theory appli- cations method vast . also number commercial fea software packages available , ansys , nastran , algor , etc . purpose chapter expose reader funda- mental aspects fea , therefore coverage extremely introductory nature . detail , reader urged consult many references cited end chapter . ; fluid dynamics ; piping analysis ; multiphysics . purposes chapter , limit basic mechanics analyses . actual mechanical component continuous elastic structure ( continuum ) . fea divides ( discretizes ) structure small finite , well-defined , elastic sub-structures ( elements ) . using polynomial functions , together matrix operations , continuous elastic behavior element developed terms element ’ material geometric properties . loads applied within element ( gravity , dynamic , thermal , etc . ) , surface element , nodes element . element ’ nodes fundamental governing entities element , node element connects elements , elastic properties element eventually established , boundary conditions assigned , forces ( contact body ) ultimately applied . node possesses degrees freedom ( dof ’ ) . degrees freedom independent translational rotational motions exist node . , node possess three translational three rotational degrees freedom . element within structure defined locally matrix form , elements globally assembled ( attached ) common nodes ( dof ’ ) overall system matrix . applied loads bound-ary conditions specified matrix operations values unknown displacement degrees freedom determined . done , simple matter use displacements determine strains stresses constitutive equations elasticity . 19–1 finite-element method modern development finite-element method began 1940s field structural mechanics work hrennikoff , 2 mchenry,3 newmark,4 used lattice line elements ( rods beams ) solution stresses con-tinuous solids . 1943 , 1941 lecture , courant 5 suggested piecewise polynomial interpolation triangular subregions method model torsional problems . advent digital computers 1950s became practical engineers write solve stiffness equations matrix form . 6,7,8 classic paper turner , clough , martin , topp published 1956 presented matrix stiffness equations 2a . hrennikoff , “ solution problems elasticity frame work method , ” journal applied mechanics , v ol . 8 , . 4 , pp . 169–175 , december 1941 . 3d . mchenry , “ lattice analogy solution plane stress problems , ” journal institution civil engineers , v ol . 21 , pp . 59–82 , december 1943 . 4n . m. newmark , “ numerical methods analysis bars , plates , elastic bodies , ” numerical methods analysis engineering ( ed . l. e. grinter ) , macmillan , 1949 . 5r . courant , “ variational methods solution problems equilibrium vibrations , ” bulletin american mathematical society , v ol . 49 , pp . 1–23 , 1943 . 6s . levy , “ structural analysis influence coefficients delta wings , ” journal aeronautical sciences , v ol . 20 , . 7 , pp . 449–454 , july 1953 . 7j . h. argyris , “ energy theorems structural analysis , ” aircraft engineering , october , november , december 1954 triangular elements employed . element type flaw creates two basic problems . element straight sides remain straight deformation . strains throughout plane stress triangular element constant . first problem , geometric one , modeling curved edges . note surface model large curvature appears poorly modeled , whereas surface hole seems reasonably modeled . second problem , much severe , strains various regions actual structure changing rapidly , constant strain element provide approximation average strain center element . , nutshell , results predicted model extremely poor . results improved significantly increasing number elements ( increased mesh den-sity ) . alternatively , using better element , eight-node quadrilateral , suited application , provide improved results . higher-order interpolation functions , eight-node quadrilateral element model curved edges provides higher-order function strain distribution . fig . 19–2b , triangular elements shaded nodes elements represented black dots . forces constraints placed nodes . nodes simplex triangular plane stress elements two degrees freedom , corresponding translation plane . thus , solid black , simple support triangles left edge represent fixed support model . also , distributed load applied three nodes shown . modeled load statically consistent actual load . 19–2 element geometries many geometric shapes elements used finite-element solution process describe finite-element solution process simple one-dimensional problem , using linear truss element . truss element bar loaded tension compression constant
